Rheumatoid Arthritis with Associated Interstitial Lung Disease

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with oral ulcers, alopecia (hair loss), and can lead to inflammation of various organs including acute pericarditis. Follicular hyperkeratosis is less commonly associated but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare disorder causing vascular inflammation throughout the body, known for its major symptom of oral ulcers. While alopecia is less common, systemic manifestations can include skin lesions and potentially pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: This inflammatory disease can affect various organs, skin (leading to follicular hyperkeratosis), and rarely the heart (acute pericarditis). Alopecia and oral ulcers are less common but possible in this condition.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
diagnoses.rationale: A condition leading to inflammation and swelling in the skin, hair, nails, and mucous membranes. It can cause oral ulcers and alopecia. Follicular hyperkeratosis is also a symptom, especially in its follicular form.

diagnoses.name: Pemphigus Vulgaris
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder characterized by blistering and sores on mucous membranes and skin, commonly affecting the mouth first with painful ulcers. Alopecia can occur due to scalp lesions.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash, which can include follicular hyperkeratosis. The condition may also involve the heart, potentially leading to pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: A disease with features of several connective tissue diseases including systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Patients may experience oral ulcers, alopecia, and potentially pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Reiter's Syndrome (Reactive Arthritis)
diagnoses.rationale: Inflammation of the joints, urinary tract, and eyes, and may include skin conditions such as follicular hyperkeratosis. Oral ulcers and acute pericarditis are less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.rationale: This nutritional deficiency can cause oral ulcers and may lead to alopecia. Follicular hyperkeratosis and acute pericarditis are less directly associated but represent possible complications if the deficiency affects overall health severely.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV infection can present with oral ulcers, severe alopecia due to folliculitis, and dermatological changes including follicular hyperkeratosis. Acute pericarditis can occur, typically as a secondary infection or associated condition.

diagnoses: Connective tissue disease-related pericarditis (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with ITP)
Epilepsy (due to CNS involvement in systemic disease)
Infectious diseases (e.g., viral encephalitis, bacterial meningitis)
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia and Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Rickettsial Diseases (e.g., Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as fever, rash (including discoid rash), joint pain/swelling (synovitis), kidney involvement (proteinuria), and may also affect the heart (pericardial effusion).

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While classically associated with joint symptoms, it can have systemic manifestations including fever and, rarely, pericardial effusion. Discoid rash is less typical.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: This disease combines features of multiple autoimmune diseases and can present with rash, fever, arthritis, pericardial effusion, and kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Though more classically associated with heart-related symptoms, it can cause fever, rash, and other symptoms due to immune complex deposition, including kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: This is specifically the kidney involvement in SLE, characterized primarily by proteinuria but also associated with systemic symptoms like fever and rash.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It can be associated with systemic symptoms, though synovitis and pericardial effusion are less typical.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Known primarily for dry eyes and mouth, it can also present with systemic features including arthritis, rash, and renal involvement. Pericardial effusion is rare.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: This group of disorders can present with a wide range of symptoms including rash, renal involvement, fever, and occasionally pericardial effusion due to inflammation of blood vessels.

diagnoses.name: Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.rationale: Following a streptococcal infection, this condition can present with fever, rash, and renal involvement, though discoid rash and pericardial effusion are not common features.

diagnoses.name: Viral Exanthem
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can present with a rash, fever, and occasionally more systemic involvement including renal and joint symptoms. Pericardial involvement would be rare.

diagnoses: Psychotic disorder due to another medical condition
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Rheumatoid Arthritis with Secondary Sjogren's Syndrome

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) with Exacerbation

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Hypermobility is a common feature.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by recurring, unwanted thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors (compulsions).

diagnoses.name: Alopecia Areata
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that causes unpredictable hair loss.

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects circulation (blood flow). It involves the nervous system and is characterized by the body's inability to properly regulate blood flow and blood pressure, leading to lightheadedness and fainting. It often co-occurs with hypermobility syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)
diagnoses.description: A developmental disorder that affects communication and behavior. While not directly linked to hypermobility or Kounis syndrome, some studies suggest a higher prevalence of ASD in individuals with connective tissue disorders.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition in which mast cells inappropriately release chemical mediators, resulting in a wide range of chronic symptoms. It can be associated with connective tissue disorders and may present with cardiovascular symptoms similar to Kounis syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when the body's immune system attacks its own tissues and organs. Symptoms vary but can include memory problems, hair loss, and cardiovascular issues.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease of the central nervous system that disrupts the flow of information within the brain, and between the brain and body. Symptoms can include memory problems.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body’s connective tissue. People with Marfan syndrome may experience features including tall stature, long limbs, hypermobility, and in some cases, cardiovascular problems similar to those in Kounis syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic digestive disease where stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining. It can lead to ulcers and is associated with laryngitis due to acid reflux.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. It includes various seizure disorders.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Chemical Sensitivity (MCS)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by severe allergic-like reactions to many different kinds of pollutants including solvents, VOCs, perfumes, petrol, diesel, smoke, and other chemicals.

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.description: A form of dysautonomia that is characterized by a significant increase in heart rate when standing up. It can lead to lightheadedness, fainting, and seizures among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.description: An open sore that develops on the inside lining of your stomach and upper portion of your small intestine. Symptoms include stomach pain, nausea, and possibly bloating or belching.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune diseases
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the body's immune system attacks healthy cells. Some autoimmune disorders can cause symptoms like ulcers, seizures, and dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: A complicated disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. It may be associated with chemical sensitivities and dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. It can include sensitivity to chemicals and disturbances in autonomic functions.

diagnoses.name: Mitochondrial Diseases
diagnoses.description: Disorders caused by dysfunction of the mitochondria. They can cause a wide variety of neurologic symptoms including seizures and muscle weakness, among others.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, potentially leading to seizures, dysautonomia, and ulcers.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Asthma (with normal pulmonary function test, considering variability)
Toxic Effects of Substances chiefly nonmedicinal as to source
Occupational Asthma (without significant changes in pulmonary function tests)
Secondary Immunodeficiency due to medication or systemic disease

diagnoses.name: Viral infection
diagnoses.description: Viral infections, such as those caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, can lead to symptoms including hearing loss (due to nerve damage or middle ear involvement), muscle pain, lymphadenopathy, and in some cases, may contribute to cognitive symptoms such as difficulty finding words. Dysosmia, or distorted sense of smell, might also be present.

diagnoses.name: Neurodegenerative disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as Alzheimer's disease or other forms of dementia can present with word-finding difficulties as an early sign. Hearing loss is also common in the elderly population, often related to these conditions. While muscle pain is not a core feature, systemic manifestations can include it. Dysosmia can occur in early stages. Lymphadenopathy is not typical and might indicate another concurrent issue.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord. It can present with muscle pain and difficulty in word finding due to cognitive involvement. Hearing loss and dysosmia are less common but can occur. Lymphadenopathy is not a standard symptom of MS but could result from an immune response or infection in a person with MS.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection transmitted by ticks. It can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including hearing loss and cognitive issues such as difficulty finding words. Muscle pain and lymphadenopathy are also common symptoms. Dysosmia is not typical but might occur in the context of neurological involvement.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: The virus can cause a wide range of symptoms, including lymphadenopathy, muscle pain, and neurological issues that could potentially cover hearing loss and word-finding difficulty. While dysosmia is not a hallmark symptom, sensorial changes can occur in later stages or as part of opportunistic infections.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that primarily affects the body's moisture-producing glands but can have systemic manifestations including nerve involvement leading to hearing loss, cognitive symptoms including word-finding difficulties, and muscle pain. Lymphadenopathy can also occur in this condition.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect any organ but most often affects the lungs and lymph nodes. It can cause lymphadenopathy, and, more rarely, hearing loss through granulomatous infiltration. Muscle pain and cognitive issues can be part of the systemic symptoms. Dysosmia might occur, depending on the organ systems involved.

diagnoses.name: Chronic fatigue syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. It can include symptoms such as muscle pain, cognitive impairments including difficulty finding words, and, in some reported cases, dysosmia. Hearing loss is not commonly associated with this condition.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Cognitive symptoms, often called 'fibro fog,' can include difficulty finding words. While hearing loss and dysosmia are not classical symptoms, sensory symptoms and anomalies can occur.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 deficiency
diagnoses.description: Can cause a wide range of neurological and physical symptoms, including cognitive impairments, muscle pain, and potentially nerve damage leading to hearing loss. Lymphadenopathy is not directly associated with B12 deficiency. Dysosmia could occur in severe cases due to neurological impact.

diagnoses: Connective Tissue Disorders (e.g., Marfan Syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome)
Diabetes Mellitus – considering the presence of hyperglycemia; complications can include hypersensitivity reactions, and potentially predispose to infections
Infectious Mononucleosis – could explain lymphadenitis, hypersensitivity reactions, and possibly indirectly lead to other symptoms due to general immune system engagement
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) – can cause lymphadenitis, predispose to vaginitis due to opportunistic infections, and cause a range of hypersensitivity reactions
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) – can cause lymphadenitis, hypersensitivity reactions, and other systemic symptoms
Sjogren's Syndrome – may present with lymphadenitis (as part of its glandular involvement), and hypersensitivity reactions, with potential secondary infections causing the other symptoms
Rheumatoid Arthritis – capable of causing lymphadenitis and hypersensitivity reactions; other symptoms might relate to secondary effects or treatments
Candidiasis – could directly cause vaginitis and indirectly be associated with laryngitis; in the context of already altered immune response, could relate to other symptoms
Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) – a severe complication of uncontrolled diabetes that might indirectly lead to most of these symptoms through complicated systemic consequences
Scarlet Fever – could potentially explain some of the symptoms like hypersensitivity reactions and lymphadenitis due to the nature of the illness
Gonorrhea – could directly cause vaginitis and potentially be involved with the other symptoms through disseminated infection or immune response
Autoimmune disorders (e.g., Sjögren's syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus)

diagnoses.name: Systemic mastocytosis
diagnoses.explanation: This rare disorder affects mast cells and can cause symptoms affecting multiple organ systems including skin (migratory pruritus), gastrointestinal (dysphagia), cardiovascular (takotsubo cardiomyopathy), and potentially angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.explanation: A genetic disorder causing recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). Some patients report transient neurological symptoms that could potentially be linked to migratory pruritus or dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.explanation: This group of diseases occurs when there is an abnormal deposition of amyloid proteins in the body, potentially affecting heart (takotsubo cardiomyopathy), peripheral nerves (migratory pruritus, dysgeusia), and gastrointestinal tract (dysphagia).

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic syndrome
diagnoses.explanation: A condition characterized by a persistently elevated eosinophil count in the blood for an unknown reason, which can cause a wide range of symptoms including dermatological (migratory pruritus), cardiovascular (takotsubo cardiomyopathy), gastrointestinal (dysphagia), and occasional angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss syndrome
diagnoses.explanation: Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, a condition that can lead to systemic vasculitis affecting various organs including the skin (pruritus), nerves (dysgeusia), heart (takotsubo cardiomyopathy), and gastrointestinal system (dysphagia). Angioedema is less commonly reported.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.explanation: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, this tick-borne illness can have neuropsychiatric and cardiovascular manifestations such as dysgeusia and takotsubo cardiomyopathy, migratory pruritus, and in rare cases, dysphagia due to neurological involvement.

diagnoses.name: C1 Esterase inhibitor deficiency
diagnoses.explanation: A deficiency in this inhibitor can lead to uncontrolled activation of the complement system, causing hereditary angioedema. While not directly linked to the other symptoms, associated gastrointestinal involvement could explain dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid syndrome
diagnoses.explanation: This syndrome results from a carcinoid tumor secreting substances such as serotonin into the bloodstream, leading to symptoms such as flushing, diarrhea (potentially related to dysphagia), heart-related issues (potentially takotsubo cardiomyopathy), but migratory pruritus and dysgeusia are less directly associated.

diagnoses.name: Paraneoplastic syndromes
diagnoses.explanation: These syndromes are caused by the immune response to a cancer, with symptoms that can sometimes mimic or indirectly cause heart issues (takotsubo cardiomyopathy), skin disturbances (migratory pruritus), and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.explanation: An autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, which can cause a wide array of symptoms including dysgeusia and dysphagia. The association with migratory pruritus, takotsubo cardiomyopathy, and angioedema is not direct but can be seen in the context of overall inflammation and autonomic dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can lead to a weakened immune system, resulting in symptoms such as lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes), pneumonia due to opportunistic infections, and hypersensitivity reactions. Malabsorption and irritated eyes can also occur as complications.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, hypersensitivity reactions, and eye irritation. Pulmonary involvement can mimic pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: SLE is an autoimmune disease that can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms include hypersensitivity reactions (such as skin rashes), lymphadenopathy, and possibly lung involvement leading to pneumonia-like symptoms. Eye irritation and malabsorption may also occur in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: Tuberculosis, a bacterial infection, primarily affects the lungs but can spread to lymph nodes and other parts of the body. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, pneumonia, and eye irritation. Immune responses to the bacteria can cause hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing malabsorption. It can also cause lymphadenopathy as part of an immune response, and some individuals may experience pneumonia due to recurrent respiratory infections.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: This type of cancer affects the lymphatic system, leading to lymphadenopathy. Patients may also experience hypersensitivity reactions, malabsorption due to involvement of abdominal lymph nodes, and pneumonia due to a weakened immune system.

diagnoses.name: Whipple's Disease
diagnoses.description: Whipple's disease is a rare bacterial infection that primarily affects the small intestine, leading to malabsorption. Symptoms can include swollen lymph nodes, recurrent pneumonia, and various hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: Behcet's disease is a rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. Symptoms include eye irritation, hypersensitivity reactions like skin rashes, lymphadenopathy, and it can also affect the lungs, mimicking pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Now known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, it is a condition that causes inflammation of blood vessels and can affect various organs, including the lungs (leading to pneumonia-like symptoms), skin (hypersensitivity reactions), and eyes (irritation). Lymphadenopathy can also be present.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: CVID is an immunodeficiency disorder that can cause recurrent infections, including pneumonia, due to a weakened immune system. Patients may also experience malabsorption, lymphadenopathy, and various hypersensitivity reactions, including problems affecting the eyes.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism may not cause noticeable symptoms in the early stages, but over time, untreated hypothyroidism can cause a number of health problems, such as obesity, joint pain, infertility, and heart disease.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by two most common symptoms - dry eyes and a dry mouth. The condition often accompanies other immune system disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus. Xerosis (dry skin) is a common symptom, along with potential respiratory system involvement.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. Inflammation caused by lupus can affect many different body systems - including your joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can affect more than just your joints. In some people, the condition can damage a wide variety of body systems, including the skin, eyes, lungs, heart, and blood vessels. Interstitial lung disease can be a complication.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys do not work as well as they should. It can lead to various complications including high blood pressure, anemia (which may cause pallor), and edema.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mainly the lungs and lymph glands. In patients with sarcoidosis, abnormal masses or nodules (called granulomas) consisting of inflamed tissues form in certain organs of the body.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia—a condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells. Red blood cells carry oxygen to the body's tissues. As the name implies, iron deficiency anemia is due to insufficient iron. Without enough iron, your body can't produce enough of a substance in red blood cells that enables them to carry oxygen (hemoglobin).

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: A rare, chronic disorder of the connective tissue involving skin thickening, spontaneous scarring, blood vessel disease, varying degrees of inflammation, associated with an overactive immune system. Autoimmune rheumatic diseases can cause widespread involvement throughout the body, including vascular manifestations, skin dryness (xerosis), and internal organ involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that causes signs and symptoms of several connective tissue diseases, such as lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It can result in features of these conditions, such as skin changes, muscle weakness, and problems with internal organs.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis C
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that causes liver inflammation, sometimes leading to serious liver damage. The hepatitis C virus (HCV) spreads through contaminated blood. While a majority of infected individuals might not show symptoms in the early stages, it can eventually lead to liver scarring (cirrhosis), which may present various non-specific systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder and a common cause of hyperthyroidism that can lead to a variety of symptoms including possible oral pain due to gum diseases, goiter which might affect the ears causing tinnitus, and rarely, epistaxis due to elevated blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Storm
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening condition characterized by an extreme overproduction of thyroid hormones (thyrotoxicosis). Symptoms can include oral pain, tinnitus, and epistaxis, as part of a systemic reaction.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can lead to symptoms like oral pain due to throat infection, liver dysfunction (potentially indirectly linked to hyperthyroidism), and generalized edema.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever and may result in migratory edema, rare instances of hyperthyroidism, and various other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure can lead to secondary complications that may manifest as oral pain (via dental issues), epistaxis due to the rupture of small vessels, tinnitus, and in some cases, could be linked with hyperthyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands responsible for keeping the eyes, mouth, and other parts of the body moist and lubricated, leading to oral pain, and possibly linked to hyperthyroidism as an autoimmune comorbidity.

diagnoses.name: Acute Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: While primarily an inflammation of the sinuses, it can cause oral pain, epistaxis, and possibly tinnitus due to pressure changes affecting the ear. Hyperthyroidism complications may indirectly aggravate symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Disease
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that lead to excessive bleeding. While not directly causing hyperthyroidism, the stress and complications from such diseases could lead to systemic symptoms including oral pain and epistaxis.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Though primarily affecting the blood's ability to carry oxygen, severe cases can lead to symptoms such as oral pain (due to ulcers), tinnitus, and, in rare cases, epistaxis. Migratory edema is less commonly a direct symptom but can be related through secondary complications.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause a broad range of symptoms depending on the type and location of the affected vessels, including oral pain, tinnitus due to auditory nerve impact, and epistaxis from nasal vessel inflammation. Hyperthyroidism may exacerbate the condition.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic digestive disease where stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to widespread metabolic disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: An umbrella term for disorders that involve chronic inflammation of the digestive tract, such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A common and serious medical illness that negatively affects how you feel, the way you think, and how you act.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chromosomal disorder in which a female is born with only one X chromosome, leading to delayed puberty among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Klinefelter Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition that results in a male born with an extra X chromosome, which can cause symptoms like delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Constitutional Delay of Growth and Puberty (CDGP)
diagnoses.description: A temporary delay in the skeletal growth and thus height and puberty, that is not due to specific pathological condition.

diagnoses.name: Otitis Externa
diagnoses.description: An inflammation or infection of the outer ear and ear canal.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono or the 'kissing disease,' this infection can lead to symptoms like fatigue, sore throat, fever, and it can also cause lymphadenitis.

An inflammatory disorder affecting multiple parts of the body. Key symptoms can include mouth sores, genital sores, inflammation inside the eye, skin rashes and lesions, and acne-like sores in body areas with hair. It may also involve vascular system inflammation, leading to chest pain and other symptoms.
A rare disorder that causes inflammation of the blood vessels in your nose, sinuses, throat, lungs, and kidneys. Symptoms include sinusitis, nosebleeds (epistaxis), ulcers, and chest pain.

An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms are varied and may include chest pain and skin ulcers.

Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is a virus that attacks the body's immune system. If not treated, it can lead to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS). Symptoms of HIV/AIDS can include periodontal disease, ulcers, and vaginitis due to immunosuppression.

A type of inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus. Symptoms can include mouth ulcers and may also lead to systemic inflammation resulting in chest pain.
Deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate can lead to various health problems, including oral ulcers, periodontal disease, and systemic symptoms such as chest pain.
An inflammation of the blood vessels. It can cause various symptoms depending on the organs affected, including chest pain, skin ulcers, and potential gum disease.
A type of blood cancer that develops in the bone marrow. Symptoms can include fatigue, frequent infections, bleeding easily (such as epistaxis), and mouth ulcers.

A condition that occurs when the body stops producing enough new blood cells. It can lead to symptoms including fatigue, recurrent infections, skin rashes, and bleeding easily, which may relate to periodontal issues.

A disease resulting from a vitamin C deficiency. It can cause anemia, debility, exhaustion, spontaneous bleeding, pain in the limbs, especially in the legs, swelling in some parts of the body, and severe gum disease (periodontal disease).

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body including joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, but it can also cause cyst formation and affect other parts of the body, including muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Often associated with POTS.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition in which mast cells release too much of their content, leading to a wide range of chronic symptoms, including orthostatic intolerance, muscle pain, and more.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by recurrent infections, which can lead to conditions promoting leukocytosis and post-nasal drip.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including muscle pain and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland is underactive and can’t produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to various symptoms including fatigue and muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have infrequent or prolonged menstrual periods or excess male hormone levels.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause systemic issues, including muscle pain and impacts on the heart that could influence POTS symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reaction
diagnoses.reasoning: Could manifest as migratory edema and migratory pruritus; however, it usually doesn't directly cause dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests or oral pain unless there's an associated angioedema that affects the throat, potentially complicating the picture.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain autoimmune conditions, such as lupus, can cause a wide range of symptoms, including kidney involvement (which could indirectly explain a urinary tract infection due to immune system disruption), oral ulcers, and potentially skin manifestations (edema and pruritus). However, autoimmune diseases would not typically present with normal pulmonary function tests if dyspnea was directly due to lung involvement.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: It can cause oral ulcers, genital ulcers, skin problems, and might lead to other systemic issues. Given its rare and complex nature, it might be considered less likely without the presence of more characteristic symptoms like genital ulcers and eye inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Typically associated with pain and swelling in an extremity, it could potentially explain migratory edema and pain. However, it does not commonly present with urinary tract infections, oral pain, or dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Could indirectly cause edema and has a relation to urinary symptoms, but it does not commonly direct cause dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests, oral pain, or migratory pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain types of hepatitis could potentially cause a constellation of symptoms including urinary changes (though less typically a straightforward UTI), and some forms of hepatitis can cause extrahepatic symptoms including skin rash and arthralgias. Oral pain and dyspnea are less typical.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Dyspnea
diagnoses.reasoning: Though this could explain dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests, it does not account for the other physical symptoms like oral pain, migratory pruritis, or edema.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause oral dryness and pain due to its effect on salivary glands, and potentially systemic issues, but it does not typically cause urinary tract infections, migratory edema, or dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain types of vasculitis can cause skin changes (such as pruritus and edema), oral ulcers, and systemic symptoms. However, the direct link to urinary tract infection and dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests would be less common.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: While diabetes can lead to urinary tract infections due to immune compromise and possibly peripheral edema, it does not typically cause dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests, oral pain in the absence of an infectious process, or migratory pruritus.

diagnoses: Blepharospasm might not commonly overlap with the other listed conditions in a straightforward way, contributing directly to a diagnosis. However, evaluating the combination of symptoms can guide towards a spectrum of possible conditions, acknowledging that these symptoms may stem from multiple unrelated disorders. Here are ten possible considerations:

Hormonal imbalances: Conditions such as thyroid disorders or polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) can lead to symptoms like menorrhagia and could indirectly contribute to headaches or hypersensitivity reactions.

Autoimmune diseases: Certain autoimmune conditions, such as Sjögren's syndrome, could explain the combination of dry eyes (leading to blepharospasm), periodontal disease, and hypersensitivity reactions.
Bleeding disorders: Some disorders that affect the body's ability to clot could lead to heavier menstrual periods (menorrhagia) and could, in theory, be related to more generalized systemic symptoms.

Migraine: While primarily associated with headaches, migraines can also induce hypersensitivity to light and sound, and in some cases might correlate with menstrual cycle changes, influencing menorrhagia.

Fibromyalgia: Known for widespread pain and sensitivity to various stimuli, could also manifest with headaches. Though less directly connected, individuals with fibromyalgia might report menstrual irregularities or exacerbation of other symptoms.

Endometriosis: Primarily associated with menorrhagia and potentially chronic pain, which can lead to headaches. While less directly linked to blepharospasm or periodontal disease, endometriosis affects systemic health and could influence a wide range of symptoms.

Neurological conditions: Some neurological disorders could present with blepharospasm and headaches as primary symptoms. Peripheral manifestations or systemic conditions might also induce hypersensitivity reactions.

Vitamin deficiencies: Certain deficiencies (e.g., vitamin B12, vitamin D) could theoretically contribute to a range of symptoms, including menorrhagia and hypersensitivity reactions, and indirectly affect dental health.

Psychosomatic disorders: Stress and anxiety can manifest with a wide range of physical symptoms, including headaches, menstrual irregularities, and hypersensitivity reactions. They can also exacerbate conditions like blepharospasm.
Environmental sensitivities: Exposure to certain environments or substances can lead to hypersensitivity reactions and could indirectly exacerbate other symptoms like headaches or dental conditions.
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Acute myocardial infarction with cardiogenic shock
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) exacerbation due to allergic reaction
Infectious diseases (e.g., bacterial or viral gastroenteritis)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with visceral involvement
Anisakiasis (due to ingestion of raw or undercooked fish)
Drug reaction (with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms)
Drug reactions (including allergic and non-allergic drug reactions)
Asthma exacerbation triggered by an allergy
Allergic Rhinitis with a coexisting allergy
Urticaria (Hives) due to an allergic reaction
Acute Bronchitis with an allergic component
Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) with allergic rhinitis
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) - if history of smoking or long-term exposure to lung irritants
Neurogenic shock due to spinal cord injury
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with kidney involvement

diagnoses.name: Sudden sensorineural hearing loss
diagnoses.description: A rapid loss of hearing in one or both ears due to damage to the inner ear or auditory nerve, which may accompany symptoms such as dizziness and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system), leading to weakness, coordination and balance difficulties, and sensory problems.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms, including severe headache, phonophobia (sensitivity to sound), visual disturbances, numbness or tingling, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium spread by ticks. It can cause neurological symptoms such as facial palsy, hearing loss, and peripheral neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Schwannoma (Acoustic Neuroma)
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Symptoms may include hearing loss, tinnitus, dizziness, numbness and weakness on one side of the face.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus. It may also lead to a feeling of fullness in the ear and affect balance.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves, leading to muscle weakness and numbness that can escalate to paralysis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) damages the immune system and can lead to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS). Neurological symptoms may include peripheral neuropathy and cognitive impairments.

diagnoses.name: Neurosyphilis
diagnoses.description: The infection of the brain or spinal cord caused by the bacteria Treponema pallidum. It can manifest as hearing loss, weakness, visual problems, and altered mental status.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause a variety of symptoms depending on the tumor's location, including hearing loss, numbness, weakness, and cognitive changes.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around nerve fibers, causing inflammation and pain. Symptoms include fatigue, difficulty walking, numbness, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die within minutes. Symptoms include trouble walking, speaking, and understanding, as well as paralysis or numbness of the face, arm, or leg.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant). Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, problems with vision, vomiting, and mental changes.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: An uncommon type of stroke caused by bleeding on the surface of the brain. It's a medical emergency. Symptoms can include a sudden severe headache, often described as 'the worst headache ever,' along with nausea, vomiting, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis. Symptoms can quickly worsen and can be fatal if not treated promptly.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Can lead to a variety of neurological problems, including feeling numb in the hands and feet, trouble walking, memory loss, and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: An abscess is a collection of pus that has built up within the tissue of the body. A brain abscess is a pus-filled swelling in the brain. Symptoms can include headache, fever, vomiting, and neurological problems such as seizures or weakness.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP)
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder characterized by progressive weakness and impaired sensory function in the legs and arms. The disorder, which is sometimes considered an autoimmune disease, is caused by damage to the myelin sheath of the peripheral nerves.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often on one side of the head. Patients can experience sensory disturbances (parasthesia), scintillating scotoma (scintillation), and sensitivity to sound (phonophobia).

diagnoses.name: Migraine without Aura
diagnoses.description: A common type of migraine characterized by a pulsating headache often on one side of the head, accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and phonophobia, but without the visual and sensory disturbances (aura) seen in Migraine with Aura.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headache
diagnoses.description: This headache presents with bilateral, non-pulsating, band-like pain across the forehead. It can sometimes be associated with phonophobia or photophobia, but lacks the significant visual or sensory symptoms like scintillation or parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headache
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder known for causing extreme headache attacks of severe, unilateral pain. It's not typically associated with parasthesia or scintillation but can involve restlessness and phonophobia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke', a TIA can present with sudden headache, dizziness, parasthesia, and sometimes temporary visual disturbances, which might mimic migraine aura without the severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic, immune-mediated condition that affects the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include parasthesia, visual disturbances (including scintillation), and sometimes a headache, along with a wide range of neurologic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Brain Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: An abnormal bulge in a blood vessel in the brain which can cause severe headache, parasthesia, visual disturbances, and other symptoms if it leaks or bursts.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Crisis
diagnoses.description: Severe elevation in blood pressure can lead to headaches, blurred vision (which could be mistaken as scintillation), and sometimes sensory deficits (parasthesia). Immediate medical attention is required.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, including parasthesia, and sometimes loss of awareness.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from restricted blood flow in the arteries at the base of the brain. Symptoms may include vertigo, dizziness, headache, and visual disturbances, including those similar to scintillation.

diagnoses: Migraine (with aura, specifically with symptoms like scintillation)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by neurological phenomena (aura) that precedes the actual headache. Symptoms may include visual disturbances (scotoma), speech difficulties (aphasia), and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headache, difficulty speaking (aphasia), weakness, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) temporarily blocks blood flow to the brain and causes similar symptoms to a stroke, such as aphasia, weakness, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause symptoms depending on the tumor's location; these may include headaches, speech problems (aphasia), muscle weakness, and vision problems (scotoma).

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include muscle weakness, tingling, trouble with coordination, vision problems, and speech disorders (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Venous Sinus Thrombosis
diagnoses.description: A blood clot of the dural venous sinuses, which drain blood from the brain. Symptoms may include headache, abnormal vision (scotoma), weakness, and speech disturbances (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Hemiplegic Migraine
diagnoses.description: A rare form of migraine headache where sufferers experience weakness on one side of their body (hemiplegia) in addition to the headache and vision disturbances such as scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Symptoms can include visual disturbances and aphasia depending on the type of seizure.

diagnoses.name: Moyamoya Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare, progressive cerebrovascular disorder caused by blocked arteries at the base of the brain. The typical symptoms include headaches, seizures, weakness, speech disturbances, and visual problems.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic Encephalopathy
diagnoses.description: A term for brain dysfunction resulting from various causes like toxins, liver failure, renal failure, and electrolyte imbalances. Symptoms can include altered mental status, vision disturbances, weakness, and speech issues.

diagnoses: DRESS Syndrome (Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms)
Lymphoma (cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, specifically mycosis fungoides can present with skin rashes similar to those described)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis)
Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia
Vasculitis (such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis or eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS-CoV-2 infection, COVID-19)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with Associated Interstitial Lung Disease

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including pericarditis, lymphopenia, pericardial effusion, potentially lead to hemolytic anemia, and less commonly associate with lichen planus.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily affecting joints, it can also cause pericarditis, pericardial effusion, and anemia, as well as lymphopenia in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reason: This disease combines features of multiple autoimmune diseases and can present with pericarditis, pericardial effusion, lymphopenia, and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Primarily affecting salivary and lacrimal glands, but can also cause systemic complications including lymphopenia and has been associated with pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: A rare autoimmune disorder that combines autoimmune hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, which can be associated with other autoimmune manifestations like pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Adult Still's Disease
diagnoses.reason: This inflammatory disease can present with symptoms such as pericarditis and pericardial effusions, and can sometimes lead to lymphopenia and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily affecting the lungs, it can involve the heart causing pericarditis and pericardial effusion, lymphopenia, but less commonly associated with hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.reason: This condition can lead to pericarditis and pericardial effusions. Lymphopenia and anemia can also occur due to systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reason: Certain types of lymphoma can present with lymphopenia due to bone marrow infiltration, pericardial effusions due to direct involvement or obstruction, anemia, and rarely skin manifestations that could mimic lichen planus.

diagnoses.name: Parvovirus B19 Infection
diagnoses.reason: This viral infection can cause a transient aplastic crisis leading to hemolytic anemia in patients with chronic hemolytic anemias, can potentially lead to pericarditis or pericardial effusions, and lymphopenia during acute infection.

diagnoses: Infectious Diseases (e.g., Viral or Bacterial infections that can cause secondary immune responses)
Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia (as part of an autoimmune syndrome)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's Granulomatosis)

diagnoses.name: Lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's marked by symptoms like skin rash, joint pain, and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. Inflammation can affect other parts of the body, leading to hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease known for its distinctive skin rash and muscle weakness. The rash can be patchy and polycyclic; it is often accompanied by systemic symptoms, including anemia.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include rash and flu-like symptoms. In later stages, it can mimic several autoimmune diseases.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis of the skin. It features joint pain and swelling (arthropathy) and may include conditions like anemia.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, most notably the lungs and lymph glands. Skin rashes and arthritis are common symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Erythema multiforme
diagnoses.description: A skin condition considered to be a hypersensitivity reaction to infections or drugs. It is characterized by target-like lesions or rashes, which can be annular and polycyclic.

diagnoses.name: Systemic sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: A group of rare diseases that involve the hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It can include symptoms like skin changes, arthropathy, and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed connective tissue disease
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that displays features commonly seen in lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including nonscarring alopecia, skin rash, and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Still's disease (Adult-onset Still’s disease or AOSD)
diagnoses.description: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis that features fevers, rash, and joint pain. Hemolytic anemia and other systemic symptoms may be present.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (for isolated psychosis without other systemic causes)
Hematologic malignancies (such as leukemia or lymphoma)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the kidneys, skin, and blood cells. Oral ulcers, hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and proteinuria are common manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of immune thrombocytopenia and autoimmune hemolytic anemia, with possible involvement of other organs leading to symptoms like oral ulcers and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder with overlapping features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including symptoms like oral ulcers, hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Renal involvement can manifest as proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: Though primarily affecting joints, it can present systemic symptoms including Sjögren's syndrome (which can cause oral ulcers), anemia of chronic disease, and in rare cases thrombocytopenia and proteinuria due to kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease primarily affecting the salivary and lacrimal glands, leading to dry mouth with possible oral ulcers. Can be associated with systemic features including hematological abnormalities and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)
diagnoses.description: A rare blood disorder characterized by clotting in small blood vessels (microangiopathy), leading to low platelet count (thrombocytopenia) and hemolytic anemia. Renal involvement can lead to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder causing increased clotting. It is associated with thrombocytopenia, and patients can have hemolytic anemia. Renal artery thrombosis can lead to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare vascular disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. Symptoms can include oral ulcers, various skin lesions, and eye inflammation, and it can lead to kidney problems manifesting as proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
diagnoses.description: A rare, acquired, life-threatening disease of the blood characterized by destruction of red blood cells, bone marrow failure, and thrombosis. It can sometimes present with hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by the triad of hemolytic anemia, acute renal failure (which can manifest as proteinuria), and thrombocytopenia. It is typically caused by infection by certain strains of E. coli.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Hepatitis B or C Related Cryoglobulinemia
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
